block.p: North Korea May Agree To Multiparty Arms Talks The Bush administration said North Korea appeared ready to agree to an American proposal for multiparty talks to try to resolve the impasse over the North's refusal to dismantle its growing nuclear weapons program. An announcement in Moscow that North Korea had accepted the proposal for multiparty talks was the foremost indicator.

An announcement in Moscow that North Korea had accepted the proposal for multiparty talks was the foremost indicator.

Iraqi Military Tribunal Planned The United States has plans to create a special tribunal composed of Iraqi judges to try Saddam Hussein for crimes against humanity if he is captured, officials said. In moving toward an Iraqi tribunal, the Bush administration is rejecting any significant role for the United Nations or an international tribunal.

An explosion near the Baghdad airport and a shooting attack 50 miles northeast of the capital killed two American soldiers and wounded five, military officials said, shattering a rare two-day stretch of relative quiet in which no soldiers had died.

Secretary of State Colin L. Powell approved payment of a $30 million reward to the informant who led American soldiers to Saddam Hussein's sons. He said he hoped the payment would speed efforts to find Mr. Hussein, the State Department said.
A Plea to Saudi Arabia United States senators sought to compel Saudi Arabia to intensify its antiterrorism efforts.

New Curbs on Palestinians The Israeli Parliament voted to block Palestinians who marry Israelis from becoming Israeli citizens or residents, erecting a new legal barrier as Israel finished the first section of a new physical barrier against West Bank Palestinians. Opponents called it a racist measure that threatened to divide thousands of families.
Ex-Dictator Now Candidate Efraín Ríos Montt, a former military dictator accused of presiding over atrocities during the harshest era of Guatemala's civil war, registered as a presidential candidate.

Vatican Urges Lawmakers To Reject Same-Sex Unions The Vatican urged Roman Catholic lawmakers and others in a 12-page document to fight back against the spread of laws that recognize same-sex couples, calling support for such legislation ''gravely immoral.''

Pentagon Official to Resign John M. Poindexter, the official who oversaw a plan for the Pentagon to run a terrorist futures-trading market, is resigning under pressure, a senior defense official said.
Courts Short of Money The agency that runs the federal courts urged judges to defer some trials until October, when its new fiscal year begins. It later backtracked.

Recall Deadline Approaches The two most prominent potential Republican candidates in California, Arnold Schwarzenegger, the actor, left, and Richard J. Riordan, below, former mayor of Los Angeles, continued their discussions to decide which of them would run in the recall race for governor. The deadline for candidates to file their intentions is Aug. 9.

Archbishop Replaces Lawyers The new archbishop of Boston, Sean P. O'Malley, has replaced the lawyers representing the archdiocese against about 500 claims of sexual abuse with a lawyer known for swiftly settling such cases.

Times Names Managing Editors Jill Abramson, the Washington bureau chief of The New York Times, and John M. Geddes, the newspaper's deputy managing editor, were appointed managing editors of The Times, effective Sept. 2.

Rebuilding Officials Resolve Major Differences Officials overseeing the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site said that they had resolved most of their differences over Daniel Libeskind's plan, which is likely to be built in substantially recognizable form.
Davis's Family in Spotlight The murder of Brooklyn Councilman James E. Davis has pushed his family into an unfamiliar spotlight.

Prison Transfer Support Democratic leaders in the Connecticut legislature agreed to let Gov. John G. Rowland transfer 2,000 inmates out of state in exchange for money for projects that might reduce the prison population.

School Sued Over Oustings A class-action lawsuit charges that officials at a Brooklyn high school routinely told difficult students that it was time to go elsewhere, though New York State law provides that students have the right to remain in school until they are 21.
Yankees Trade at Deadline The Yankees added acquired the All-Star Aaron Boone, a big hitter, from the Cincinnati Reds.
The Red Sox, who have been making trades to try to surpass the Yankees, obtained Jeff Suppan from the Pittsburgh Pirates, adding a solid starter to a rebuilt pitching staff.

Court Rules Against I.B.M. A federal court ruled that I.B.M. violated age discrimination laws when it converted its traditional pension plan to one that cut benefits to about 130,000 workers and retirees.
Phone Company Ban Proposed Federal officials proposed barring MCI from winning new government contracts for up to three years. MCI will have 30 days to respond to the proposal.

Strong Quarter for Economy The U.S. economy expanded at a 2.4 percent annual rate in the second quarter, pulled up by rising military and consumer spending, and a long awaited revival in business investment in computers and software.

Recording Industry Challenged The recording industry's pursuit of online music swappers was challenged by an Internet provider's lawsuit questioning the legality of the industry's tactics and by an inquiry opened in the U.S. Senate.
